So, you're interested in cyber security...

## Where to Start?

```bash
user@my-linux-distro:~#  whoami
beginner 
```

Find what industry you’d like to work-in and start learning! 
There is a lot of choice but opportunities may be limited. 
If you aren’t sure what industry you'd like to work-in, then look at job boards and understand the requirements for getting into particular industries.

---

## Some Resources

Below are some of the resources that I've used.

### Educational

Understand your industry and what the requirements are proir to paying for anything.

- [Udemy](https://www.udemy.com/) *`I only bought courses when they were $11 USD`*

- [Pluralsight](https://www.pluralsight.com/)

- [Coursera](https://www.coursera.org/)

- [LinkedIn Learning](https://www.linkedin.com/learning/)

- [Western Governors University](https://www.wgu.edu/) 

If you decide to enroll to [WGU](https://www.wgu.edu/)then you can find my referral here --[WGU Referral](https://infl.tv/o67J). 


You get subscriptions to [Udemy](https://www.udemy.com/), [Pluralsight](https://www.pluralsight.com/), and [LinkedIn Learning](https://www.linkedin.com/learning/) as a [WGU](https://www.wgu.edu/) student.
I'd caution that you really should be a 'self-starter' and very responsible to attend [Western Governors University](https://www.wgu.edu/).

Do your research before joining any platform, or University!
I chose to pay for courses on [Udemy](https://www.udemy.com/) prior to pursuing higher education. 
Once I understood the material then I knew I was ready to work towards the degree and certifications.
This was a necessary path for me understanding the industries that I wanted to work in required a combination of certifications and the degree.

I chose to attend [WGU](https://www.wgu.edu/) because it provided me with certifications and the degree.
Things I required but you may not. 
You don't need a degree or certifications necessarily to get into cyber.

### Getting Hands On

The material in this section is great for mixing things up a bit. 
Once upon a time I would watch youtube videos on hacking and mess with vulnhub.  
Then it turned to me taking udemy classes.  
I'd take a break from Udemy, and pivot over to Hackthebox or Tryhackme.

- [TCM Security](https://tcm-sec.com/)

- [Tryhackme](https://www.tryhackme.com/)

- [HackTheBox - Academy](https://academy.hackthebox.com/) and my --[Referral](https://referral.hackthebox.com/mz9PNmZ)

- [Terminus](https://web.mit.edu/mprat/Public/web/Terminus/Web/main.html)

- [OverTheWire](https://overthewire.org/wargames/)

- [Vulnhub](https://www.vulnhub.com/)

- [Blue Team Labs](https://blueteamlabs.online/)

- [Immersive Labs](https://www.immersivelabs.com/)

- [PWNED Labs](https://pwnedlabs.io/)

### Make Learning Fun

Learning can be fun when you find others to compete with in **"Capture the Flag"** **(CTF)** competitions. 
This is something I do with fellow [WGU](https://www.wgu.edu/) students.

- [picoCTF](https://picoctf.org/)

- [CTFTIME](https://ctftime.org/)

- [NCAE CYBER GAMES](https://www.ncaecybergames.org/)

- [NATIONAL CYBER LEAGUE](https://nationalcyberleague.org/)

---

> Cyber roles will likely require constant learning. Start now!

I'm a security student that enjoys participating in Cyber Club events like catpure the flag (CTF) competitions.
Here you'll find walkthroughs, write-ups, educational notes, and cyber related news here.
